description: From Middle English mighty, mightie, mighti, myghty, miȝty, maȝty, from Old English mihtiġ, mehtiġ, meahtiġ, mæhtiġ (“mighty”), from Proto-West Germanic *mahtīg (“mighty”), from Proto-Germanic *mahtīgaz (“mighty”), equivalent to might +‎ -y.
Cognate with Scots michty, mychty, Saterland Frisian machtich, Dutch machtig, German Low German machtig, German mächtig, Swedish mäktig.

examples: He's a mighty wrestler, but you are faster than him.
He gave the ball a mighty hit.
Having listened attentively to the statement of Wandle Schoonhoven, giving an occasionable grunt, as he shovelled a mighty spoonful of Indian pudding into his mouth  […]

entries.meaning: Accomplished by might; hence, extraordinary; wonderful.

examples: Tonight's a mighty opportunity to have a party.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, dialect) Very; to a high degree.
examples: You can leave that food in your locker for the weekend, but it's going to smell mighty bad when you come back on Monday.
Pork chops boiled with turnip greens makes a mighty fine meal.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, rare) A warrior of great strength and courage.
